newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia late palm olein stable, export taxes up.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia late palm olein stable, export taxes up.

text.p: Indonesian palm olein prices were stable in late trading on Wednesday, with the government announcing higher export taxes in January for crude palm oil and three products.
They said olein was generally quoted at 1,450-55 rupiah/kg in Jakarta, unchanged from the opening, but offers were also heard at 1,445 rupiah. No crude palm oil deals were heard.
The traders said the state logistics agency BULOG was on its second day of market operations to keep a lid on prices, selling olein directly to consumers at 1,300 rupiah/litre.
"The export tax was within market expectations," one said.

The tax on crude palm oil had been raised to $46.80 per tonne in January from $44.72 in December, the Finance Ministry said on Wednesday. The tax on RBD palm olein had been raised to $47.60/tonne in January from $41.30, while that on RBD palm oil had been increased to $39.76/tonne from $33.04/tonne.
The tax on crude olein had been increased to $51.10/tonne in January from $44.80 in December.
Traders said that although the market operations by BULOG had made the market cautious it had had no significant impact on prices because of strong gains in the Malaysian market.
"The market is not quite certain how much oil BULOG will pump into the market," one trader said. "Prices will only weaken if BULOG channels a lot of oil into the market."
Traders said BULOG was not expected to push large quantities of olein into the market because the market operations, which began on Tuesday, end on January 15.
BULOG chief Beddu Amang said on Wednesday that the agency had imported a total of 52,000 tonnes of olein from Malaysia, with the last batch of 13,000 tonnes set to enter the country.
The market operations are to ensure local prices do not rise during the Moslem Ramadan fasting month and Eid al-Fitr.
